channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis Updates: Israel Targets Hezbollah Official in Strike in Damascus
item.description: Two Israeli officials described the attack as an attempt to assassinate a Hezbollah official involved in weapons smuggling. It came as Israel continued to press its campaign in Lebanon against Hezbollah, an Iranian proxy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Nobel Physics Prize Awarded for Pioneering A.I. Research by 2 Scientists
item.description: With work on machine learning that uses artificial neural networks, John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton “showed a completely new way for us to use computers,” the committee said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor, Cade Metz and Katrina Miller
item.media:description: John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton, pictured onscreen, were announced as recipients of the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physics in Stockholm on Tuesday.

item.title: So, Are You Pregnant Yet? China’s In-Your-Face Push for More Babies.
item.description: The government is again trying to insert itself into women’s childbearing decisions, knocking on doors and making calls with questions some find downright invasive.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Propaganda artwork in Miyun, a district of Beijing, depicting a couple with three children and including slogans promoting childbearing.

item.title: For Many Israelis, Oct. 7 Never Ended
item.description: The Hamas-led attacks that day shattered Israelis’ faith in the state, and the year of war that followed has deepened society’s divisions. Yet many find hope in the people’s resilience.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Kfar Aza last month.

item.title: A Cartel Double-Cross Turns a Mexican State Into a War Zone
item.description: An explosive deception has ripped apart one of Mexico’s most powerful criminal groups, the Sinaloa cartel, and ignited a war between the rival factions.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Paulina Villegas and Meridith Kohut
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police guarding a crime scene last month in Culiacán, Mexico.

item.title: Russia Pushes Forward in Ukraine’s East After Fall of Vuhledar
item.description: Russian troops have now entered Toretsk, a strategic hilltop city, and are pressing with assaults elsewhere in the Donetsk region.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen near Toretsk, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, in September.

item.title: India’s Elections Offer Mixed Results for Modi
item.description: Two closely watched elections, in Haryana and the turbulent Jammu and Kashmir, kept the surprises coming after this summer’s shocking national outcome.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli, Hari Kumar and Showkat Nanda
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition Congress Party celebrating on Tuesday in Srinagar, in Jammu and Kashmir. Congress and its allies won overwhelmingly in the territory.

item.title: U.K.’s MI5 Chief Says Russian Spies Seek to ‘Generate Mayhem’
item.description: The head of Britain’s domestic security service said Russia’s military intelligence service was pursuing “dangerous actions conducted with increasing recklessness.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ken McCallum, director general of MI5, speaking in west London on Tuesday.

item.title: France’s Government Survives a No-Confidence Vote
item.description: The outcome was not a surprise but signals a treacherous road ahead for the country’s divided legislature.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France in Paris on Monday. A no-confidence vote against his government failed on Tuesday.

item.title: What Is Hamas Capable of After a Year of War?
item.description: The Palestinian militant group fired rockets at Israel on the anniversary of its Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene of a rocket assault in Kfar Chabad, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Israelis Hold Sorrowful Vigils on Anniversary of Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: Israelis gathered on Monday to mourn those killed or abducted on the deadliest day in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of victims of the Oct. 7 attacks gathered at the site of the Nova music festival in southern Israel on the morning of the anniversary.

item.title: Israel Faces 4-Front War Year After Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: Gaza, Lebanon, Iran and Yemen: Israeli forces exchanged fire with militants backed by Tehran on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Bilal Shbair and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion on Monday in the Lebanese village of Qmatiyeh near Beirut.

item.title: As a Massacre Unfolded in Haiti, a Frantic Call: ‘Send for Help'
item.description: When a gang assaulted a town in central Haiti last week, one woman called a local community leader begging for assistance. The massacre left at least 78 civilians dead.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams
item.media:description: Families from Pont-Sondé, a town in central Haiti attacked by a gang last Thursday, gathered at a park in the nearby city of Saint-Marc.

item.title: Mozambique’s 2024 National Elections: What to Know
item.description: Four candidates are vying for the presidency in a country that has faced a yearslong ISIS-backed insurgency. The election is also a test of the sway of former independence movements.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Tavares Cebola
item.media:description: A wall plastered with election campaign posters for Daniel Francisco Chapo, the candidate for the governing party, Frelimo, in Maputo, Mozambique, on Tuesday.

item.title: As I Am: L.G.B.T.Q. in Japan
item.description: ‘We don’t want to send the message to the younger generation that we’re people who have to hide ourselves.’
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee, Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Satoko Nagamura, right, with her partner, Mamiko Moda, and their son in Tokyo.

item.title: In This Office, the Fading Dream of a Unified Korea Lives On
item.description: On paper, five South Korean officials are the governors of North Korean provinces. Their goal is reunification, but fewer and fewer Koreans share it.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting Tuesday of the “governors” appointed by South Korea to run provinces in North Korea. They have no real power in the North; the appointments are a way for the South to claim sovereignty there.

item.title: How Harrods of London Is Dealing With a Sexual Abuse Scandal
item.description: The 175-year-old department store is trying to make amends for alleged abuse by its former owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, even while shoppers seem undeterred.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: People walking past the Harrods department store in London in 2022. Mohamed Al Fayed, who owned the store from 1985 until 2010, allegedly used it as a hunting ground for young women whom he would select from the storeroom floor and then elevate to work in his personal office.

item.title: Climate Change Increased Rain and Wind Speeds of Helene
item.description: In cooler times, a similarly rare storm over the Southeast would have delivered less rain and weaker winds, a team of scientists concluded in an analysis.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Mike Belleme for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage in Swannona, N.C., on Sept. 28.

item.title: Volkswagen’s Woes Reflect a Stagnant German Economy
item.description: Germany’s largest automaker rode a wave of strong sales for years, but lagging demand and pressure from China are forcing it to consider layoffs.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volkswagen has said it is considering job cuts and factory closings in Germany for the first time in its 87-year history.

item.title: Ruth Glacier in Alaska Hides America’s Deepest Gorge
item.description: A famed explorer was sure the ice hid something profound. Ninety years later, scientists have put forth the strongest evidence yet that he was right.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Jason Gulley
item.media:description: Chloe Steiner, a mountain guide, descended into a cave inside Ruth Glacier.

item.title: Israel Sends More Soldiers Into Lebanon as Strikes Hit Beirut and Damascus
item.description: In an attack of its own, Hezbollah fired 180 “projectiles” into Israel, according to the Israeli military, which said most were intercepted.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer, Ronen Bergman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from multiple Israeli airstrikes targeting the southern suburbs of Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: Brazil Unblocks X After Musk Backs Down
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said Tuesday that Elon Musk’s social network could return in the country after a monthlong ban because the company had complied with the court’s orders.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters criticizing the Brazilian Supreme Court’s decision to ban X during a demonstration in São Paulo last month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: An Israeli Airstrike in Syria
item.description: Plus, revisiting Oppenheimer’s Communist ties.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A residential building on the western outskirts of Damascus, Syria, yesterday.

item.title: Yoav Gallant, Israel’s Defense Minister, Postpones Trip to DC, US Says
item.description: Yoav Gallant and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were expected to discuss Israel’s response to the Iranian missile assault on Israel last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant, the Israeli defense minister, in Tel Aviv, last year.

item.title: Biden Excoriated Netanyahu on Israel’s Conduct in the War, Woodward Book Says
item.description: The book, “War,” lays bare just how frustrated the president has become with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the war in Gaza began.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with President Biden at the White House in July.

item.title: Toronto Woman Is Accused of Murdering 3 in Serial Killings
item.description: Victims who were found in a span of three days in Canada last week included two men whom the police said the suspect had attacked at random.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Steve Russell/Toronto Star via Getty Images
item.media:description: The police outside of the Toronto home of Sabrina Kauldhar, who is accused of killing three people last week.

item.title: What We Know About the Israeli Forces Fighting in Lebanon
item.description: The Israeli military has sent troops from four divisions across the border into Lebanon, but has not publicly disclosed how many.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles staging near the border with Lebanon earlier this month.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Killed Nasrallah’s Replacement and ‘the Replacement of the Replacement’
item.description: Hashem Safieddine had been expected to succeed Hassan Nasrallah, his cousin. It was not immediately clear who “the replacement of the replacement” was.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss
item.media:description: Hashem Safieddine, center, in a southern suburb of Beirut, in August.

item.title: Art or Trash? It Can Be a Fine Line.
item.description: Two beer cans were displayed in a Dutch museum. Then they were accidentally thrown out.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: Does My Home Have Lead Pipes? And What Can I Do About Them?
item.description: New rules will require utilities to replace lead pipes nationwide. That will take time, but you can protect yourself by taking these steps.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lead pipe in a Chicago home. It’s possible to identify lead pipes with a magnet and by lightly scratching the metal.

item.title: Iran Crisis Ignites New Debate About Trump’s Nuclear Deal Exit
item.description: President Donald J. Trump labeled it “the worst deal in history.” But critics of the withdrawal say it prompted Iran to accelerate its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: In May 2018, President Donald J. Trump announced that the United States would no longer abide by the Iran nuclear deal.

item.title: U.N. Official Took $3 Million in Secret Gifts From Businessman
item.description: The official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a businessman to whom he steered the organization’s funds, a court ruled. The U.N. got a song about the ocean.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A U.N. court found last week that Vitaly Vanshelboim had committed fraud and “blatant misconduct” by failing to disclose gifts from a British businessman.

item.title: Japan Says It Doctored Photo of Cabinet Ministers
item.description: The episode provided political fodder for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s critics and highlighted the country’s generally high standard of dress.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: New Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba of Japan, center front, posing for an official photo with his cabinet in Tokyo this month.

item.title: Biden Requires Lead Drinking-Water Pipes to be Replaced Nationwide
item.description: The “historic” rule aims to eliminate a major source of lead poisoning and comes a decade after a drinking-water crisis in Flint, Mich.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: President Joe Biden in Milwaukee on Tuesday. “I’m here today to tell you that I finally insisted that it gets prioritized and I’m insisting it get done,” he said about the order to replace lead pipes throughout the country.

item.title: Oppenheimer’s Communist Past Draws New Attention
item.description: As a group of historians and a top biographer square off, proponents of a middle path see a tangled life in which the superstar of science was, and was not, a true Communist at the same time.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad

item.title: Athens Democracy Forum: Where Is Global Politics Headed?
item.description: Voters have more opportunities than ever in 2024 to shape history in their countries, but war, technology and other forces pose a powerful threat, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:description: Voters in France, above, and 20 other countries cast their ballots in the European Parliament election in June.

item.title: A Young Activist Arrested in Zimbabwe Holds Onto Her ‘Why’
item.description: Namatai Kwekweza said she remained committed to her advocacy for change in Africa, despite a harrowing experience in Zimbabwe.
item.dc:creator: Ginanne Brownell
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Namatai Kwekweza at the Athens Democracy Forum last year. She was held for 35 days after being taken off a plane in July and arrested in Harare, Zimbabwe.

item.title: Athens Democracy Forum: Seeking the Road to Peace in the Middle East
item.description: Panelists at the Athens Democracy Forum discussed the widening conflict and the challenge of getting the warring parties to a consensus.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A view from Ashkelon, Israel, on Oct. 1 of Israel’s Iron Dome antimissile system intercepting rockets from Iran.

item.title: Does India Offer a Glimmer of Hope for Democracy?
item.description: Prime Minister Modi was re-elected, but his party fell short in dominating Parliament. Was that an inflection point for the world’s largest democracy?
item.dc:creator: David Belcher
item.media:description: Supporters of Prime Minister Narendra Modi celebrated after India’s election in June. His Bharatiya Janata Party failed to win a simple majority in the lower house of Parliament, and Mr. Modi now leads a coalition government.

item.title: Athens Democracy Forum: Young Activists on What Drives Them
item.description: Six young people from around the world who attended the Athens Democracy Forum spoke about what drives them and the challenges they face.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Athens Democracy Forum: Can Money Help Save Democracy?
item.description: Experts on a panel in Athens last week debated how a growth in organizations aimed at countering a rise in autocracies could help turn the tide.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen

item.title: Athens Democracy Forum: Democracy at the World’s Ballot Boxes
item.description: Much of Earth’s population has been voting this year. Where democracies are strained and stressed, is there room for optimism?
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in Soweto during South Africa’s general election in May.

item.title: A Year Later, Biden Faces the Limits of U.S. Influence in the Mideast
item.description: In the immediate aftermath of the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7, the president stepped in to support Israel, counsel moderation and seek a lasting peace.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, lit a yahrzeit candle for the victims of the Oct. 7 attacks with Rabbi Aaron Alexander at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Washington Worries the Israelis Will Bomb Iran’s Nuclear Sites. But Can They?
item.description: For 22 years, Israeli forces have planned for this moment. But it seems unlikely that they will strike Iran’s nuclear facilities in the next round of retaliation, or that they would be successful without American help.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: An Israeli F-15 flying over southern Israel in March. The country is capable of striking targets deep inside Iran, but would prefer to have the support of the United States.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israelis and Palestinians Mourn a Year of Loss
item.description: Plus, Chappell Roan navigates the demands of fame.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of victims of the Oct. 7 attacks at the site of last year’s Nova music festival.

item.title: Netanyahu Rebukes Macron’s Call for Arms Embargo on Israel
item.description: The French leader said countries should stop supplying weapons to Israel, arguing that providing arms while demanding a cease-fire is inconsistent. That drew the Israeli leader’s fury.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday.

item.title: Israel challenges U.N. court’s jurisdiction to issue a warrant for Netanyahu’s arrest.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Karim Khan, the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in February.

item.title: Viktor Bout Is Trying to Sell Weapons to the Houthis, Western Officials Say
item.description: The Russian arms dealer, who was freed in a prisoner exchange with the United States, is negotiating with the militant group in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Maria Turchenkova for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian arms dealer Viktor A. Bout was released by the Biden administration in December 2022 after serving less than half of his sentence in U.S. federal prison.

item.title: Pro-Israel and Pro-Palestinian Students at Columbia Hold Side-by-Side Protests
item.description: During tense but somber vigils on the university library steps, students and their supporters expressed outrage and sorrow.
item.dc:creator: Anvee Bhutani and Sharla Steinman
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside Columbia University, people gathered in support of Israel. On the campus, students held adjacent rallies, one for Israel and another for Palestinians.

item.title: Israel’s Hostage Families Vow to Keep Fighting as War Escalates, One Year On
item.description: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr

item.title: In Mexico, a Mayor Is Brutally Killed Just Days After Taking Office
item.description: The gruesome killing represents yet another challenge for the country’s new president, who faces increasing pressure to show progress in the fight against violent cartels.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Mexican security forces on Sunday at the scene where Alejandro Arcos Catalán, the mayor of Chilpancingo, Mexico, was killed.

item.title: Why Israel’s Hostage Families Are Turning on Their Government
item.description: Family members of hostages held in Gaza are escalating their tactics to push for a cease-fire deal. They say the government is dragging out the war in Gaza for political reasons, and putting their family members’ lives at risk.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Shakked Auerbach, Ben Laffin and Guy Barak

item.title: Missile Hits Near Ukrainian Air Base as Russia Expands Air Attacks
item.description: The strike is part of a broader campaign of air assaults by Moscow aimed at degrading Ukraine’s military infrastructure and wearing down its air defenses.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A man walks next to parts of a Kinzhal Russian hypersonic missile recovered from an airstrike in Ukraine last month.

item.title: Emirates bans pagers and walkie-talkies on flights after attacks.
item.description: The move comes after communication devices used by Hezbollah members exploded last month, killing dozens of people.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: Lebanese Middle East Airlines (MEA) and Emirates Airlines planes on the tarmac of Beirut-Rafic Al Hariri International Airport in July.

item.title: In London, a Pro-Palestinian Protest Disrupts the Launch of an American Mural
item.description: The U.S. ambassador Jane Hartley was en route to the dedication of a climate-themed mural in London by Shepard Fairey, who created the iconic Obama ‘Hope’ poster. But then a protest began.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters disrupt the dedication ceremony for Shepard Fairey’s latest project, a mural on climate change, in London on Monday.

item.title: Tunisia’s President Cruises to Landslide Re-Election Victory
item.description: President Kais Saied’s apparent landslide re-election is the latest sign that authoritarianism has returned to the birthplace of the Arab Spring.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Supporters of President Kais Saied of Tunisia in Tunis after exit poll results were announced on Sunday.

item.title: Key Moments in the Middle East War Since Hamas’s Oct. 7 Attack on Israel: Timeline
item.description: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel and the 12 months of conflagration that has followed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Victims lie on a highway in the Sderot area of southern Israel following the attack by Hamas on Oct. 7.

item.title: Russia Sentences 72-Year-Old American on Charges of Fighting for Ukraine
item.description: Stephen James Hubbard, a native of Big Rapids, Mich., whose family says is an English teacher, was sentenced to six years and 10 months in a penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video provided by the Moscow City Court of Stephen James Hubbard at a court hearing in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Ex-Philippine President, Under Investigation for War on Drugs, Returns to Politics
item.description: Rodrigo Duterte, who retired in 2022 after a six-year term as president, filed papers to run for mayor of Davao, his family’s political stronghold.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Francis R. Malasig
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte, in white mask, attending the inauguration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines, left, in Manila in 2022.

item.title: Hostages’ Families Endure Surreal Wait on Anniversary of Oct. 7 Attacks
item.description: More than 60 living hostages, and the bodies of about 35 others who are believed to be dead, are still in Gaza, according to the Israeli authorities.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: “I feel the hostage situation has been put to the back,” said Ofri Bibas-Levy, Yarden Bibas’s sister.

item.title: Palestinians in Gaza Reflect on One Year of Israel’s War With Hamas
item.description: The war has killed tens of thousands and devastated entire cities, leaving many in Gaza without a home and fueling a humanitarian catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians fleeing Israeli bombing in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, last year.
